briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 8, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Climate Crisis: Deepening Direct Threats and Economic Repercussions
sections.content: Recent reports emphasize the deepening direct and visible impacts of climate change. Domestically, concerns are being raised about the occurrence of large-scale wildfires in winter [1], underscoring the need for a bold shift in climate crisis awareness and practical actions in daily life [4]. Internationally, there are observations that climate change threatens the very existence of winter sports, with the use of artificial snow in the Winter Olympics being cited as an example [5]. Some scientists express concern that the current climate crisis may have reached an irreversible level [27], and warn that existing models underestimate the risk of economic collapse due to the climate crisis [36]. Furthermore, widespread economic repercussions are materializing, such as rising insurance costs and reduced coverage due to climate change [34].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Carbon Neutrality Policies and Implementation Status
sections.content: Domestically, various efforts are underway to achieve carbon neutrality, but the outcomes show somewhat mixed results. Gangneung City presented a positive example by successfully overcoming a water shortage crisis caused by climate change, earning recognition as the nation's top institution [3]. In contrast, Gunpo City's basic local government carbon neutrality plan received a 'failing grade,' revealing deficiencies in policy implementation [6]. The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education is promoting carbon neutrality practices in all schools by 2026 [8, 11], Ulleung County has launched an electric vehicle dissemination project to create an eco-friendly island [9], and Suwon City Council passed a carbon neutrality ordinance, establishing a legal framework [10]. In addition, practical efforts in daily life are steadily expanding, including Ulsan Jung-gu's migratory bird ecological exploration and carbon neutrality campaign [7, 13, 14], reducing single-use items in public offices [12], and senior resource circulation guardian activities [16].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Escalating Conflicts over Renewable Energy Expansion and Transmission Grid Infrastructure
sections.content: The transition to renewable energy is a key driver in responding to the climate crisis, but challenges in infrastructure construction arising during this process are becoming prominent. While there is positive news that Chungju City has been selected for the renewable energy convergence support project for nine consecutive years [20], severe conflicts are emerging in the Jeonnam region, known as the 'renewable energy mecca,' surrounding the construction of transmission towers [21]. This is linked to the 'national backbone power grid' project [22], and opposition movements are showing signs of spreading nationwide [23]. The unresolved issues from the past 'Miryang struggle' are being brought up again [24], and residents of Yeongam County are expressing 'fear' due to ultra-high voltage lines [26], indicating that local residents' concerns and resistance are intensifying. This suggests an urgent need for social consensus and ensuring fairness in the energy transition process.

sections.title: ğŸŒ Accelerated Climate Action and New Approaches in the International Community
sections.content: The international community is making substantial progress in responding to climate change, with efforts accelerating at various levels [29]. In Northern Ireland, the establishment of a climate change monitoring body is planned [28], and scientists are exploring innovative ways to slow down climate change, such as sinking trees in the Arctic Ocean or focusing on the role of rare moss species [31, 33]. Discussions towards sustainability are also active in the sports sector, with proposals like adding cyclocross as an additional Winter Olympics event, considering climate change [35]. Furthermore, three U.S. statesâ€”California, Hawaii, and New Yorkâ€”are pursuing legislation to hold major polluting corporations accountable in response to rising insurance premiums due to climate disasters [37], taking concrete action to achieve climate justice.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing reconfirmed the severity of the climate crisis, while also highlighting various response efforts underway both domestically and internationally, and the challenges encountered in that process. A comprehensive and integrated approach for a sustainable future is becoming increasingly important. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: These US states want polluters to pay for the rising insurance costs of climate disasters
articles.description: Proposals by California, Hawaii and New York lawmakers aim to hold fossil fuel industry accountable for soaring ratesAs climate disasters drive up the price of home insurance, three US states are considering empowering their state prosecutors to sue major polluters for their role in those rising costs.Lawmakers in California, Hawaii and New York have introduced measures which would authorize their attorneys general to sue fossil fuel companies on behalf of residents whose insurance premiums have

summary.phenomenon: Three U.S. statesâ€”California, Hawaii, and New Yorkâ€”are advancing legislation to hold major polluters accountable for rising home insurance premiums caused by climate disasters.
summary.cause: Climate disasters have been identified as the cause of increasing home insurance premiums, with the fossil fuel industry considered to have played a role in these rising costs.
summary.outlook: Should the legislation pass, these states' attorneys general would be empowered to sue fossil fuel companies on behalf of residents.
